Graphical abstract A large number of crystal defects were found on the Pd/o-WO3 surface, which improved the efficiency of cellulose conversion to C2 alcohols. Converting cellulose into C2 alcohols presents a sustainable alternative to fossil fuels, contributing to the development of eco-friendly and economically viable biofuels and chemicals. Tungsten oxide (WO3) is a key solid acid catalyst for this process, yet limited research explores its diverse morphologies and unique catalytic effects. This study investigates diverse WO3 morphologies (nanosheets, nanoflowers, nanoblocks, and tetrahedral octahedra) in combination with Pd for converting cellulose to C2 alcohols. Optimized conditions with Pd/o-WO3 catalyst resulted in the highest C2 alcohols (ethylene glycol and ethanol, 80.9 %), notably yielding 64.8 % ethylene glycol. Extensive characterizations and DFT calculations reveal the smaller element occupancy rates and a longer W-O bond length led to a large number of crystal defects over Pd/o-WO3. It facilitated the formation of W5+–OH sites and Pd-O(H)-W interactions, further synergistically enhancing hydrogenation ability and acidity. Designed experiments to elucidate cellulose conversion pathways, including hydrolysis, retro-aldol condensation, and hydrogenation. This study emphasizes the unique impact of WO3 morphologies and underscores the importance of supporting crystal defects for catalytic performance in eco-friendly biofuel and chemical production. Keywords Cellulose conversion Tungsten trioxide Morphological impact Crystal defects Alcohols Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The excessive dependence on fossil resources, such as coal, oil, and natural gas, not only depletes energy reserves but also causes environmental pollution. Hence, finding an alternative green resource for sustainable development is crucial [1,2]. Cellulose, the predominant carbon source in lignocellulose derived from non-food sources like trees, straw, and discarded cotton fibers [3,4], offers significant potential as a substitute for fossil energy in the sustainable production of fuels and chemicals. As a D-(+)-glucose pyranose linear homopolymer linked by β-1,4-glycosidic bonds [5,6], cellulose can be efficiently converted into high-value platform compounds through hydrothermal catalysis, including ethylene glycol (EG)[7], ethanol (EtOH)[8], 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PG)[9], lactic acid (LA)[10], Ketone alcohol [11], and others. Notably, EG finds widespread use as a precursor for polyester fibers, antifreeze, coolant, and energy carrier [12], while EtOH serves as a versatile low-carbon fuel, solvent, and disinfectant [13]. Consequently, the development of efficient catalysts for the conversion of cellulose to C2 alcohols (EG and EtOH) holds immense research potential and significance. Currently, a multitude of supported catalysts have been developed for the conversion of cellulose into valuable chemicals. Although oxides, molecular sieves, and other carbon materials are commonly utilized as supports, most of these exhibit proclivity toward catalyzing the synthesis of C6 alcohols. The pioneering work by Atsushi Fukuoka and Paresh L. Dhepe [14] showcased the capability of Pt/γ-Al2O3 in converting cellulose into sugar alcohols, predominantly sorbitol and mannitol. Akshay R. Mankar et al. [15] prepared heteropolyacid (HPA)/zirconia and Ru/C catalysts for one-pot conversion of raw cellulose into high-yield value-added products such as hexitol and ethylene glycol. Ribeiro et al. [16] employed carbon materials as supports and loaded Ru metal, revealing that the Ru/CNT catalyst effectively converted cellulose into sorbitol with over 60 % selectivity. However, the materials containing W species have recently gained attention for their ability to promote the production of C2 alcohols. Zhang's team pioneered the use of W species in cellulose conversion, achieving a maximum ethylene glycol yield of 61 % with the Ni-W2C/AC catalyst [17]. They later developed a series of bimetallic catalysts based on W, exploring synergistic effects between W and metals such as Ni, Pd, Ru, and Ir, with the Ni–W/SBA-15 catalyst yielding up to 75.4 % EG [18]. Additionally, they found that WP could be used as a support to prepare Ni-based catalysts for this process [19]. Subsequently, Lucília Sousa Ribeiro and colleagues prepared a nitric acid-modified carbon nanotube-supported Ru catalyst and an untreated carbon nanotube-supported tungsten catalyst. When physically mixed and used in a one-pot reaction with cellulose, these catalysts yielded 41 % ethylene glycol within just 5 h [20]. Their subsequent improvements led to the development of Ru-W/CG [21] and Ni–W/CNT [22] catalysts, which showed even better performance in converting cellulose into ethylene glycol. Applying these catalysts to lignocellulosic biomass, they achieved an ethylene glycol yield of over 35 %. Gao et al. [23] recently prepared a nickel-tungsten co-doped spherical carbon-based catalyst using a one-pot hydrothermal carbonization method, with glucose as the carbon source. The resulting WCx catalyst led to a 100 % conversion of cellulose and a 69 % selectivity for ethylene glycol. Among the varied W-contained species, WO3 is particularly noteworthy due to its excellent acidic properties [24]. Unlike other acidic metal oxides like SiO2 and ZrO2, WO3 has been found to significantly promote the cleavage of C2-C3 bonds in glucose, making the formation of ethylene glycol and other low-carbon alcohols more feasible [25–27]. Liu et al. [28] introduced WO3 during cellulose conversion with a Ru/C catalyst, resulting in a substantial shift towards the production of ethylene glycol. Cao et al. [29] developed a Ni-WO3/SBA-15 catalyst, achieving a 70.7 % EG yield. Wu et al. [30] discovered that modulating the WOx content can adjust catalyst acidity, enhancing cellulose hydrolysis, inhibiting glucose isomerization to fructose, and boosting ethylene glycol yield. Additionally, some studies found that the unique ability of WO3 to form nonhomogeneous HxWO3 species in water aids in cellulose hydrolysis and C–C bond cleavage in sugars, setting it apart from catalysts that quickly convert glucose to hexanol [31,32]. This mechanism highlights the role of WO3 in selectively producing C2 alcohols. Furthermore, existing research emphasizes the profound influence of catalyst morphology on catalytic efficacy. Disparate morphologies can exert influence on intermolecular forces, alter interface structures, and lead to the formation of distinct functional sites during catalyst preparation [33]. For instance, Liao et al. [34] fine-tuned the interface structure of Rh particles and CeO2 by altering the CeO2 morphology, leading to discernible alterations in surface oxygen vacancy density and catalytic activity. Similarly, Cai et al. [35] found that the electronic effect of strong metal support interaction between Pd and In2O3 was significantly influenced by their morphology. Notably, WO3 also has diverse morphologies, and studies have demonstrated that these morphological variations have distinct catalytic effects on processes such as the photocatalytic oxidation of benzene to phenol [36] and photoelectrochemical water splitting [37]. This indicates that the structure and surface electron gap of WO3 with diverse morphologies have an impact on the performance of the catalyst. [38] Thus, the morphology of WO3 may also play a role in altering the catalytic performance of cellulose conversion to C2 alcohols, but this aspect remains unexplored in the literature, and its intrinsic reasons are still unclear. Moreover, Palladium (Pd) is renowned for its excellent hydrogenation capability [39] and can form synergistic interactions with tungsten-containing materials, which facilitates the hydrogenolysis of cellulose. Leal et al. [40] prepared a Pd-W2C/C catalyst for the production of EG from cellulose. Their findings revealed a significant interaction between Pd and W, promoting a multi-step reaction and enhancing EG production. Pd can also form synergistic interactions with WO3 [41], which is particularly beneficial for cellulose conversion. Chu et al. [42] demonstrated that incorporating Pd into Cu-WOx/SiO2 substantially improved the production efficiency of C2 alcohols. In this study, we prepared a series of Pd/x-WO3 catalysts with different WO3 morphologies, including nanosheets, nanoflowers, nanoblocks, and tetrahedral octahedra, to investigate their effect on the catalytic conversion of cellulose to C2 alcohols. Through optimizing the reaction conditions, a high total C2 alcohols selectivity of 80.9 % with EG selectivity reaching 64.8 % was acquired over Pd/o-WO3 (Orthogonal tungsten trioxide). Various characterizations were conducted to explore the microstructural differences and the chemical state of elements. Subsequently, the hydrogenation and acidic properties of these catalysts were investigated to establish the structure-performance relationship. The designed experiments provided insights into the reaction path and mechanism. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and catalyst preparation Sodium tungstate (Na2WO4·2H2O, 99.5 %), palladium nitrate (Pd (NO3)2, 4-5 wt%, diluted to 5.04 g/L), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 38 %), nitric acid (HNO3, 65–68 %), sodium chloride (NaCl, 99.5 %), acetone (99.5 %), sodium borohydride (98 %), microcrystalline cellulose (25 μm), D-glucose anhydrous (99 %), fructose (99 %), mannose (99 %), sorbitol (98 %), ethanol (99.7 %) and ethylene glycol (98 %) were all purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All reagents were used without further processing. Various morphologies of WO3 were prepared by introducing different inducers and adjusting the concentration of H+ in the solution. For the production of o-WO3 nanosheets, 0.50 g of Na2WO4·2H2O was dissolved in 22 mL of deionized water and thoroughly mixed. Subsequently, 0.45 mL of HCl (38 %) was gradually added under continuous stirring until the solution turned light yellow. 11 mL of acetone was then introduced, and stirring continued for 30 min until complete mixing. The resulting solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 140 °C in an oven for 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, the grey-blue solid was filtrated, washed, dried overnight at 60 °C in a vacuum drying oven, and calcined at 250 °C for 3 h to obtain o-WO3 nanosheets. For the synthesis of h-WO3 nanoflowers, 2.00 g of Na2WO4·2H2O was dissolved in 40 mL of deionized water, and 6 mL of 1 M HNO3 solution was added. The solution was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and kept at 180 °C for 4 h. Following filtration, washing, and drying, the resulting solid powder was calcined at 350 °C for 3 h to yield h-WO3 nanoflowers. Similarly, m-WO3 nanoblocks was obtained by dissolving 2.00 g of Na2WO4·2H2O in 40 mL of deionized water, adding 20 mL of 5 M HNO3 to the solution, stirring for 30 min, heating at 180 °C for 4 h, subsequently washing and drying overnight at 60 °C. The calcination step was performed at 350 °C in air for 3 h. To synthesize c-WO3 regular octahedrons, 3.30 g of Na2WO4·2H2O and 5.85 g of NaCl were initially added into 70 mL of deionized water to form a transparent solution. HCl was then added until the pH reached 3.5. The solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C in an oven for 24 h. After cooling, the resulting product was separated by filtration, washed, dried overnight at 60 °C, and calcined at 350 °C for 4 h. Pd-loaded WO3 catalysts were synthesized by a wet impregnation method. Typically, 200 mg of WO3 was dispersed in 50 mL of deionized water with continuous stirring. Then, a certain amount of Pd(NO3)2 solution, based on a theoretical 2 % mass fraction of Pd, was added. Next, excessive sodium borohydride was introduced to the solution and stirred for 1 h to ensure full reduction of Pd ions. The samples were then obtained by filtration, washing, and drying at 60 °C overnight in a vacuum oven, denoted as Pd/x-WO3 (where x represents the type of WO3). 2.2 Activity Measurements The catalytic test was conducted in a 100 mL reaction vessel. Initially, 50 mg of catalyst and 100 mg of microcrystalline cellulose powder or other raw materials, along with 30 mL of deionized water, were sequentially added. Following several purges of the reactor with H2, the reactor was pressurized with 5.5 MPa H2 (99.999 %) and heated to 245 °C for 4 h at a stirring speed of 600 rpm. The collected reaction products were analyzed using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, Agilent 1260, Shanghai, China) equipped with an 87-H column and a refractive index detector (RID). The mobile phase consisted of a 2 mmol/L H2SO4 aqueous solution, flowing at a rate of 0.6 mL min−1. The cellulose conversion and product selectivity are calculated as follows: X cellulose % = m rawcellulose - m residualcellulose m rawcellulose × 100 Y product % = mol carboninaspecificproduct mol carboninrawcellulose × 100 To ensure result reliability, all tests were conducted in triplicate, and the error was kept below 3 %. Turnover number (TON) values were calculated according to the following equation. TON = Amount of C2 alcohols (μmol)/amount of catalyst (μmol) [43,44]. 2.3 Catalysis characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a Japanese Science Ultima IV diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα (λ = 0.15406 nm) radiation source. The scanning rate was set at 10° min−1 within the 2θ range of 10 − 80°. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of various catalysts was determined using an Automatic specific surface area analyzer (Tristar 3000). Before testing, samples were pretreated at 200 °C for 3 h under a vacuum atmosphere. The content of Pd and W elements in the catalyst was measured via Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometry (ICP-OES) using AGILENT ICP-OES 730. The morphology of the catalysts was observed using a Sigma500 scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Carl Zeiss AG, Jena, Germany). The size distribution of metal particles and the lattice fringes were examined through scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM, Talos F200S). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on an ESCALAB Xi+ electron spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, US) using 300 W Al Kα radiation. Raman spectra of all samples were collected at room temperature using a 532 nm He Ne laser on Thermo Fisher DXR2. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were recorded using an EMX micro A300 spectrometer at −196 °C. The data was quantified using Bruker WINEPR software. For H2 and NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD, NH3-TPD), the sample was heated to 120 °C at a rate of 2 °C min−1, treated with Ar flow for 60 min, then cooled to 50 °C for H2/NH3 adsorption with 5 vol% H2/Ar or NH3/Ar. After adsorption saturation, the samples were heated to 900 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C min−1. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy of pyridine adsorption (Py-IR) was performed on Thermo Scientific (Nicolet 380). Initially, the sample was pretreated under a dynamic vacuum of 350 °C for 1 h and then dropped to 40 °C to record the background spectrum. Subsequently, the samples were exposed to pyridine for 10 min, and spectra were collected. Desorption was performed at 150 °C under dynamic vacuum conditions, and the IR peaks were monitored. 2.4 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations The formation energy (ΔEv ) of oxygen vacancy on the o-WO3 (220) surface and h-WO3 (220) surface was calculated using the DMol3 code. The change-correlation interaction was treated by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with PBE functional with long-range dispersion correction via the TS scheme. An all-electron double numerical atomic orbital augmented by double-numerical + d function (DND) was used as the basis set, with a cutoff radius of 4.5 Å. Brillouin zone integration was sampled with the 3 × 3 × 1 k-points using the Monkhorst − Pack scheme for surface calculations. To obtain convergent results in the geometry optimization step, the tolerance of energy, maximum force, maximum displacement, and self-consistent field (SCF) were set to 2.0 × 10−5 Ha, 0.004 Ha/Å, 0.005 Å, and 1.0 × 10−5 Ha, respectively. In this work, the WO3 (220) surface slab was constructed with two atomic layers. The bottom layer was constrained at their lattice positions. The vacuum space along the z direction was set to 15 Å to avoid interactions between periodic slabs. The formation energy (ΔEv ) of oxygen vacancy was defined as: ΔEv = Ev − E0 + μo , where Ev , E0 , and μo represent the total energy of the WO3 (220) surface slab, the energy of the WO3 (220) surface slab with oxygen vacancy, and the chemical potential of oxygen, respectively. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 One-pot conversion of cellulose to EG 3.1.1 Evaluation of catalytic performance The catalytic efficacy of four distinct morphologies of pure WO3 in cellulose hydrogenation was initially assessed (Fig. 1 a). Cellulose conversion and product distribution were monitored over a 4 h of reaction period under initial 5.5 MPa hydrogen conditions at 245 °C. Notably, cellulose remained incompletely converted over pure WO3 variants. The resulting products exhibited a minimal presence of polyols but a significant amount of LA. According to the conventional conversion pathway, cellulose, upon hydrolysis to glucose, underwent substantial isomerization to fructose, which was subsequently converted to LA through retro-aldol condensation and dehydration reactions [45]. These processes took place over the WO3 catalyst due to the presence of water-tolerant Lewis acid W6+ centers, basic oxo species (W = O groups), and a hydrogen-bond network within the surface water layer. Upon loading Pd nanoparticles, significant changes in catalytic performance were observed. As depicted in Fig. 1b, Fig. S1 and Table S1, cellulose was converted after 4 h over the Pd/o-WO3, Pd/h-WO3, and Pd/m-WO3 catalysts under the same conditions, suggesting that the introduction of metal sites promoted the reaction process and enhanced cellulose conversion. Additionally, the product distribution differed significantly from that of pure WO3, with the main product shifting from LA to EG and EtOH. This underscored the substantial contribution of metal nanoparticles to the alteration of the reaction path due to the reconstruction of the active sites. Unlike the glucose isomerization to fructose over WO3 support, the Pd/x-WO3 catalysts promoted the cleavage of C–C bonds in glucose and its selective conversion into C2 alcohols (EG and EtOH). Specifically, Pd/o-WO3 exhibited the highest selectivity of C2 alcohols at approximately 80.2 %, with EG selectivity reaching 64.8 %. This is a notably high yield of C2 alcohols compared to previous studies (Table S2). The selectivity of Pd/h-WO3 for C2 alcohols was only 69.6 %, and the selectivity for EG decreased to 49.4 %. Pd/m-WO3 displayed a similar selectivity for C2 alcohols (69.4 %) as the Pd/h-WO3 catalyst, but the selectivity of EG was only 44.5 %. However, it was worth noting that Pd/c-WO3 exhibited poor performance, with cellulose conversion reaching only ∼ 75.0 %. The selectivity of total C2 alcohols was 35.1 %, including 27.3 % of EG. The significant differences in the product distribution among the four catalysts suggested the morphology of WO3 has a significant effect on the catalytic activity of the Pd/x-WO3 catalysts. Further characterization of the intrinsic influencing factors was required. 3.1.2 Optimization of reaction conditions Table 1 illustrated the impact of temperature, pressure, time, and catalyst dosage on the catalytic conversion of cellulose to C2 alcohols over Pd/o-WO3. At 215 °C, cellulose could not be fully converted, and the selectivity of C2 alcohols, especially for EG, was quite low. It indicated that low temperatures were not conducive to the hydrolysis and transformation of cellulose. As the temperature increased, cellulose conversion reached 100 %, with C2 alcohols selectivity reaching its maximum at 245 °C. Further increase in the temperature resulted in a decline in C2 alcohols selectivity, which was attributed to the further transformation of C2 alcohols into smaller molecules. Additionally, adjusting the pressure revealed a significant increase in C2 alcohols selectivity from 3.5 to 4.5 MPa, indicating the promotional role of hydrogen. Subsequently, the selectivity of C2 alcohols remained nearly constant with the sufficient hydrogenation ability. Besides, cellulose was fully converted within 2 h, suggesting the efficiency of the Pd/o-WO3 catalyst. With an extended reaction time, the selectivity of C2 alcohols gradually increased, reaching its maximum at 4 h. Then it showed a decreasing trend, possibly due to the further transformation of C2 alcohols. Furthermore, the influence of catalyst loading on product selectivity was explored. As the catalyst-to-cellulose ratio decreased, the yield of EG slightly decreased. This indicated more catalysts accelerate the formation of intermediate product glycolaldehyde, and promote the formation of ethylene glycol and ethanol [46,47]. Therefore, the conditions of 0.05 g catalyst, 0.1 g cellulose, 245°C, and 5.5 MPa H2 were selected for economic efficiency and safety considerations. Besides, the recyclability of the Pd/o-WO3 catalyst was investigated, as shown in Fig. S2. It was observed that the total cellulose conversion remained consistent even after five runs. However, the selectivity of EG and EtOH exhibited a minor decrease after the initial cyclic reaction, followed by stabilization. The XRD patterns (Fig. S3) of Pd/o-WO3 post-reaction closely resembled that of the fresh catalyst. Moreover, the ICP analysis (Table S3) of the final reaction solution detected trace amounts of Pd and W, indicating reasonable stability of the catalyst. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 Structural properties SEM images revealed distinct morphologies for the four types of WO3. The o-WO3 sample (Fig. 2 a-b) displayed an accumulation of nanosheets, while the h-WO3 sample (Fig. 2c-d) exhibited a nanoflower-shaped structure composed of multiple nanorods. In contrast, the m-WO3 sample (Fig. 2e-f) featured a nano-block shape, and the c-WO3 sample (Fig. 2g-h) showcased a regular octahedron shape. Correspondingly, XRD patterns in Fig. S4 indicated that these WO3 samples matched different crystal phases. The o-WO3 sample was aligned with the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards card number 97–008-2941 (JCPDS No. 97–008-2941), and corresponds to the orthogonal crystal phase. The h-WO3, m-WO3, and c-WO3 samples matched the hexagonal (JCPDS No. 97–003-2001), monoclinic (JCPDS No. 97–008-0057), and cubic (JCPDS No. 97–020-2875) crystal phases, respectively. Based on these diverse WO3 morphologies, Pd metal was loaded, resulting in an actual Pd loading of approximately 1.7 wt% for the four Pd/x-WO3 catalysts, as revealed by ICP results (Table S4). N2 adsorption–desorption curves of these catalysts in Fig. 3 a revealed a type H3 hysteresis, indicating an irregular distribution of pore structures attributed to flat slit structures, cracks, and wedge-shaped structures. The BET surface areas (Table S5) of these catalysts were all below 10 m2 g−1, indicating small surface areas with few mesopores. XRD patterns of Pd-loaded WO3 samples (Fig. 3b) retained the same peaks as pure WO3 samples, with no observable peaks for Pd or PdO. It suggested that the addition of Pd species did not affect the crystals of WO3 and affirmed the high dispersion of Pd species [48]. Subsequently, the XRD pattern of these catalysts after a 4 h reaction was observed. Fig. S3 revealed that Pd/o-WO3, Pd/h-WO3, and Pd/m-WO3 catalysts almost maintained their original patterns, whereas the Pd/c-WO3 catalyst exhibited significant changes. Furthermore, the XRD patterns of the Pd/c-WO3 catalyst after 1 h of reaction also indicated a phase change (Fig. S5), suggesting that c-WO3 could not maintain its original crystalline phase during the reaction. This likely contributed to its poor catalytic performance. Therefore, Pd/c-WO3 was excluded from further discussion to eliminate performance differences caused by crystal phase changes. To obtain precise phase composition and lattice parameter information, Rietveld refinements were made to the XRD data of the three Pd/x-WO3 samples (Fig. 3c-e). The refined simulation mode matched well with the experimental data, indicating good correspondence on the crystal phases. However, unlike x-WOx samples (Table S6- 7), the occupancy rates of W and O greatly varied among the Pd/x-WOx samples (Table S8- 9). Specifically, the occupancy of W1 in Pd/o-WO3 was 0.994, and that in Pd/h-WO3 was 0.995, while the occupancy of W2 in Pd/m-WO3 was 0.998. The greater decreasing trend of W occupancy in the Pd/o-WO3 catalyst possibly suggested richer crystal plane defects on the catalyst surface. Raman spectroscopy also revealed distinct characteristic peaks corresponding to different crystal phases (Fig. 3f). The orthogonal phase WO3 exhibited peaks at 252, 323, 690, and 850 cm−1 [49]. The spectral bands at 243, 325, 690, and 850 cm−1 were attributed to the basic mode of crystalline hexagonal phase WO3 [50,51]. Peaks at 270, 325, 713, and 806 cm−1 were characteristic of monoclinic tungsten oxide [52]. Notably, the scattering peaks in o-WO3 and h-WO3 samples had a widened half-peak width compared to the sharp scattering peaks of m-WO3, indicating the presence of a large number of defect energy levels in their structures [53]. Next, the differences in the microstructures were investigated. The elemental mapping of Pd/o-WO3 in Fig. 4 a revealed well-distributed Pd, W, and O elements. TEM images in Fig. 4b illustrated highly dispersed Pd particles on the o-WO3 support, with an average particle size of 2.79 nm. Additionally, the analysis of lattice spacing in the TEM images indicated the presence of (111) crystal faces of Pd metal nanoparticles and (220) crystal faces of o-WO3 structures on the Pd/o-WO3 catalyst (Fig. 4c). Notably, careful observation revealed white areas indicative of crystal defects on o-WO3 support, where a large number of Pd nanoparticles were distributed. These observations suggested the presence of defects over o-WO3 favored the dispersion and stability of Pd nanoparticles. Furthermore, the lattice distances of 0.182 and 0.228 nm assigned to the (220) crystal face of the hexagonal phase and the (002) crystal face of the monoclinic phase were observed over Pd/h-WO3 and Pd/m-WO3 samples, respectively. Analyzing the crystal faces found that Pd particles on these two catalysts were also primarily in the form of (111) crystal faces (Fig. 4d-e and Fig. S6), thus excluding differences caused by the Pd crystal face. Moreover, no obvious crystal defects were found over the h-WO3 and m-WO3, and the average Pd particle sizes were 3.02 and 4.13 nm, respectively. EPR spectra were also employed to accurately determine the existing defects of various samples, revealing again that Pd/o-WO3 had more defects, followed by Pd/h-WO3 and Pd/m-WO3 (Fig. 5 a)[48]. Besides, the EPR spectra of pure x-WO3, reduced x-WO3 and unreduced Pd/x-WO3 catalysts were collected to check the origin of defects. As shown in Fig. S7, no significant defects were observed on pure x-WO3 and unreduced Pd/x-WO3, but few defects were observed on the reduced x-WO3. This indicates that defects were formed during the reduction process. Also, the defect amount over o-WO3 was higher than that over other WO3. To figure out the reasons, DFT calculations were conducted to assess the defect formation energy of various samples. Based on the TEM images, the (220) crystal faces of o-WO3 and h-WO3 were selected to construct the model for data comparability (Fig. 5b-c). According to the models, the bond length of the W-O bond in o-WO3 was 1.96 Å, and the bond length of the W-O bond in h-WO3 was 1.91 Å (Table S10). Since a longer bond length suggested lower bond energy, it meant that W-O in o-WO3 might be more prone to fracture and form crystal plane defects. Further comparison of the formation of defects indeed found that h-WO3 required approximately 1 eV more energy input than o-WO3 (Fig. 5d and Table S11). This meant the defects were more easily formed over o-WO3. Additionally, the defect amount on x-WO3 is smaller than that on Pd/x-WO3, likely due to the presence of hydrogen spillover. Variations in metal-support interaction caused by different microstructures led to differing levels of hydrogen spillover, ultimately resulting in varying numbers of defects on the surface of Pd/x-WO3. Moreover, an in-depth analysis of the defect quantity of Pd/x-WO3 and C2 alcohols yield, by integrating the EPR data (Fig. 5e), unveiled a discernible linear relationship between them. This illustrated that crystal defects played a vital role in the formation of EG and EtOH. These defects not only facilitated the dispersion and stability of Pd but could also potentially alter the local electron density of the WO3 support and Pd particles, thereby influencing the overall catalytic performance. 3.2.2 Chemical states Building upon these findings, XPS was employed to discern the chemical states of various catalysts. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the curves of O 1s were divided into three peaks. The peak at 529.9 eV was attributed to lattice oxygen, the peak at 531.2 eV belonged to the defect oxygen, and the additional one at 532.5 eV was ascribed to the hydroxyl groups [54,55]. Quantitative analysis indicated a higher proportion of defect oxygen and hydroxyl groups in Pd/o-WO3 compared to other samples. Additionally, the results of infrared spectra (Fig. S8) also indicated the presence of more hydroxyl groups in Pd/o-WO3. This aligns with previous reports in the literature, suggesting the formation of hydroxylated Pd species [56,57]. The prevalence of hydroxyl species could be attributed to the role of defective oxygen, potentially altering the adsorption properties and acidic characteristics of the catalysts [58,59]. W 4f spectra of samples in Fig. 6b showed the total peak slightly shifted towards a lower binding energy in Pd/o-WO3 compared with the other two catalysts. After analyzing, the W 4f spectra could be resolved into four peaks. The peaks at 35.9 and 38.0 eV corresponded to W6+, while the peaks that appeared at 35.4 and 37.5 eV were attributed to W5+ [60]. Quantitative analysis of the area of W5+/W showed that Pd/o-WO3 had a higher percentage of W5+, about 16 %, while only a small amount of W5+ species (11 %) was present in the Pd/m-WO3 catalyst (Table S12). This suggested that the defects in Pd/o-WO3 also promoted the formation of W5+ species [61]. These species would facilitate the existence of hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface, which has been consistent with the above analysis. In contrast, fewer defects in Pd/h-WO3 and Pd/m-WO3 correspond to a small amount of W5+ species. Additionally, Pd 3d spectra of samples in Fig. 6c showed peaks slightly shifted towards higher binding energies in Pd/o-WO3 compared to the Pd/h-WO3 and Pd/m-WO3 catalysts. This phenomenon showed that there were varied degrees of electron transfer between Pd and WO3 with different crystal phases, and the strain of Pd particles was greatly affected by the crystal phases of WO3. Further analyzing the spectra found that Pd species coexisted with 0, +2, and + δ valences. Peaks at 335.5 and 340.7 eV belonged to Pd0, while small peaks at 337.3 and 342.6 eV were attributed to Pd2+ due to the inevitable surface oxidization. Besides, peaks at 336.3 and 341.5 eV contributed by Pdδ+ were found over all samples, but the percentage was higher over Pd/o-WO3. This suggested a greater electron transfer between Pd and o-WO3 support, forming stronger Pd-O(H)-W interactions [62–65]. Since the electronic states of Pd and W were related to the activation ability of feed gas and the acidic properties, which affected the catalytic performance [66], further studies were conducted on their influence. 3.3 Influence of the Structural changes Considering the reaction primarily involved the isomerization/C–C bonds cleavage at acidic sites and the hydrogenation process at metal sites, the hydrogenation ability and acidic properties of these catalysts were explored to understand the impact of the above changes on the reaction. H2-TPD curves in Fig. 6d indicated that all three catalysts have dissociation ability for H2. However, the Pd/o-WO3 catalyst exhibited a larger desorption area of H2 and a higher desorption temperature compared to the other two catalysts. It indicated that H2 was more accessible and activated over Pd/o-WO3 due to the changes in the Pd electronic state over the Pd-O(H)-W interfaces. This phenomenon favored the occurrence of the hydrogenation process [67]. Furthermore, dissociated H+ on the Pd particles might migrate into neighboring crystal defects of WO3 support, facilitating the formation of acidic W5+–OH sites as evidenced by EPR, XPS and IR analysis [27]. These acid sites further played an important role in promoting the isomerization/C–C bonds cleavage reactions. In contrast, there is relatively little electron transfer between Pd and h-WO3 or m-WO3, resulting in poor hydrogenation ability and possibly lower acidic sites at the interfaces. NH3-TPD profiles in Fig. 6e illustrated a noteworthy disparity in acidity among the Pd/o-WO3, Pd/h-WO3, and Pd/m-WO3 catalysts. Specifically, the acidity amount of Pd/o-WO3 was about 2.1 times higher than that of Pd/h-WO3, and Pd/m-WO3 exhibited negligible acidity (Fig. S9 and Table S13). Additionally, the acidity strength of Pd/o-WO3 was stronger than Pd/h-WO3 and Pd/m-WO3. Concurrently, Py-IR spectroscopy was employed to quantify the distinct types of acid sites within the catalyst (Fig. 6f and Table S14). Evidently, Pd/o-WO3 exhibited the highest acid content, comprising 189.7 μmol g−1 of B acid and 36.2 μmol g−1 of L acid. Subsequently, the acid content of Pd/h-WO3 and Pd/m-WO3 followed a decreasing trend. Investigation into the correlation between acid content and the integral defect quantity in Fig. S10- 11 demonstrated a robust linear relationship with the total acid content, consistent with the NH3-TPD results. This observation implied that the crystal defects of the catalyst facilitated the generation of acid sites, encompassing both B and L acid sites. In concert with the outcomes, the preponderance of B acid sites on Pd/x-WO3 catalysts could be primarily ascribed to the presence of W5+–OH species at the defect sites, while the prominent Lewis active sites were contributed by Pd-O(H)-W bonds [27]. Based on the above results, owing to the existence of crystal plane defects, Pd/o-WO3 revealed a high content of surface W5+–OH sites and Pd-O(H)-W interface sites. Meanwhile, the hydrogenation ability was enhanced because of the electron transfer between Pd and W. These synergistic effects significantly enhanced the efficacy of cellulose conversion into EG and EtOH over the Pd/o-WO3 catalyst. In contrast, Pd/h-WO3 and Pd/m-WO3 with a few defect sites had few acidic sites and poor hydrogenation ability, leading to an unsatisfactory performance in the cellulose conversion. 3.4 Identification of reaction mechanism and pathway Based on previous research, the conversion of cellulose into EG following hydrolysis into glucose can potentially occur through three distinct pathways. (Fig. 7 a): (i) direct hydrogenation of glucose to produce sorbitol, wherein the C2-C3 bond is cleaved to simultaneously yield EG and butanediol; (ii) initial isomerization of glucose into mannose, followed by C–C bond cleavage and subsequent hydrogenation to produce EG; (iii) a retro-aldol condensation reaction of glucose to form glycolaldehyde, subsequently hydrogenated to yield EG [28,68]. Research has demonstrated that glucose reacts with WO3, leading to the formation of mannose at the C2 position and the cleavage of the C–C bond at the β position, which releases acetaldehyde and erythritol. Subsequently, the mannose and erythritol intermediates underwent a secondary reaction, ultimately resulting in the formation of ethanol. Additionally, the isomerization step at the C2 position is reversible [69]. This indicated that paths (ii) and (iii) were similar. To further elucidate the specific reaction path over the Pd/o-WO3 catalyst, glucose, mannose, and sorbitol were used as reactants, and subjected to a 15 min reaction under the conditions of 245 °C and initial 5.5 MPa H2. Analysis of product distribution revealed only a 1.5 % EG yield from sorbitol (Fig. 7b). For mannose and glucose, similar EG and EtOH yields (about 62 %) were acquired. Calculating the TON of C2 alcohols derived from sorbitol, mannose and glucose revealed the values were 0.1, 3.9, and 4.0, respectively (Table S15). Since the value from the sorbitol pathway was much lower than that of cellulose conversion, this pathway could be ruled out. In addition, the analysis of product distribution found that the mannose-derived products contained a certain amount of mannitol, unlike those from glucose. As the products of cellulose conversion lacked mannitol, the third pathway was deemed the plausible route for the Pd/o-WO3 catalyst. Considering the electronic status of Pd particles and the formation of acidic sites, the active sites and reaction mechanisms over the Pd/o-WO3 catalyst were proposed. By utilizing the water-tolerant acid centers at high temperatures and basic oxo species on o-WO3 support, cellulose was hydrolyzed into glucose. Glucose bound to the WO3 surface at positions C1, C2, and C3. The coordination unsaturated W species at the surface defect sites interacted with the O atom of the C = O group in glucose, forming a new W-O = C bond that polarized the C = O bond. The adjacent hydroxyl groups on the surface of WO3 or Pd-O(OH)-W interfaces interacted with the α- and β- hydroxyl groups of glucose to form W-O-C2 and W-O-C3 bonds, forming a glucose-WO3 tridentate complex. This complex led to the formation of mannose through C1-C2 carbon skeleton rearrangement and C–C bond breaking, ultimately leading to the formation of glycolaldehyde [27,69]. The glycolaldehyde then migrated to the adjacent Pd particles, where it underwent hydrogenation to produce EG and EtOH. 4 Conclusion In this study, we explored the catalytic potential of four different shapes of WO3 (orthogonal nanosheets, hexagonal nanoflowers, monoclinic nanoblocks, and tetrahedral octahedra) combined with Pd metal particles for converting cellulose into C2 alcohols. Under optimized reaction conditions, the Pd/o-WO3 catalyst exhibited the highest C2 alcohols yield at 80.9 %, with a remarkable 64.8 % yield of EG. Our various characterizations revealed a significant presence of crystal defects on the Pd/o-WO3 samples, attributed to the smaller W and O occupancy rates and longer W-O bond lengths. These defects facilitated the formation of W5+–OH sites and promoted Pd-O(H)-W interactions, thereby enhancing both the hydrogenation ability of Pd particles and the acidic properties of the WO3 support. Further experiments elucidated that cellulose hydrolyzed into glucose, followed by a retro-aldol condensation reaction at the W5+–OH sites and Pd-O(H)-W interface. The intermediate product glycolaldehyde then hydrogenated on Pd particles, ultimately leading to the formation of C2 alcohols. These findings underscore the influence of catalyst morphologies and provide valuable insights for the strategic design of catalysts aimed at the conversion of cellulose. coredata.dc:description: Converting cellulose into C2 alcohols presents a sustainable alternative to fossil fuels, contributing to the development of eco-friendly and economically viable biofuels and chemicals. Tungsten oxide (WO3) is a key solid acid catalyst for this process, yet limited research explores its diverse morphologies and unique catalytic effects. This study investigates diverse WO3 morphologies (nanosheets, nanoflowers, nanoblocks, and tetrahedral octahedra) in combination with Pd for converting cellulose to C2 alcohols. Optimized conditions with Pd/o-WO3 catalyst resulted in the highest C2 alcohols (ethylene glycol and ethanol, 80.9 %), notably yielding 64.8 % ethylene glycol. Extensive characterizations and DFT calculations reveal the smaller element occupancy rates and a longer W-O bond length led to a large number of crystal defects over Pd/o-WO3. It facilitated the formation of W5+–OH sites and Pd-O(H)-W interactions, further synergistically enhancing hydrogenation ability and acidity. Designed experiments to elucidate cellulose conversion pathways, including hydrolysis, retro-aldol condensation, and hydrogenation. This study emphasizes the unique impact of WO3 morphologies and underscores the importance of supporting crystal defects for catalytic performance in eco-friendly biofuel and chemical production.
